facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 202 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 202 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated August 1, 1962 of Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 213 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated August 1, 1962, of the Mysore High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 213 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 1, 1964 by DAS GUPTA J. with SUBBA RAO J., RAGHUBAR DAYAL J dissenting.

anchor.surface_text: April 1, 1964. The Judgment of SUBBA RAO and DAS GUPTA JJ. was delivered by DAs GUPTA J. RAGHUBAR DAYAL J delivered a dissenting opinion.

facts.text: Appellant was registration clerk in Haveri Post Office, Mysore State.

anchor.surface_text: DAS GUPTA, J.-The appellant, who was a registration clerk in the Haveri Post Office in the Mysore State, was tried by the Sessions Judge,

facts.text: Appellant tried by Sessions Judge, Dharwar on charges under s.52, s.53 and s.55 of Indian Post Office Act.

anchor.surface_text: Dharwar, on charges under s. 52, s. 53 and s. 55 of the Indian Post Office Act.

facts.text: On 18th October 1955, registered letter containing half portion of ten-rupee note and petition by Muppayyagonda received at Haveri Post Office at 4.30 p.m. from Kabbur Branch Post Office.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that on the 18th October 1955 a registered letter companytainin half portion of a ten-rupee numbere and petition on behalf of one Muppayyagonda asking for the said numbere to be exchanged for a fresh numbere was received at the Haveri Post Office at 4.30 p.m. from the Branch Post Office at Kabbur.

facts.text: Appellant detained the registered envelope on 18th October 1955 instead of despatching it that day.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was a, registration clerk at Haveri at the time, however, detained the registered envelope instead of despatching it that very day as he should have done.

facts.text: Appellant despatched the envelope on the next day, 19th October 1955.

anchor.surface_text: He despatched it the next day.

facts.text: Prosecution alleged appellant removed half portion of ten-rupee note and altered petition and list of registered articles to cover up.

anchor.surface_text: It was the prosecution case that the appellant removed the half portion of the ten-rupee currency numbere from inside the envelope and to companyer up his misconduct made alterations in the petition companytained in the envelope and in the list of registered articles.

facts.text: Misconduct discovered when Reserve Bank of India made enquiries as no note enclosed with petition.

anchor.surface_text: All this was discovered, it is said, when the Reserve Bank of India, to which this envelope was addressed made enquiries in the matter on finding that numbernote had been enclosed with the petition.

facts.text: Appellant admitted envelope received at Haveri Post Office on October 18, 1955 and not despatched that date.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant admitted that the envelope was received at the Haveri Post Office on October 18, 1955 and also, that he did number despatch it on that date.

facts.text: Appellant claimed envelope received at 5.30 p.m. on 18th October 1955, too late for despatch, despatched on 19th.

anchor.surface_text: His case was that it was received at about 5.30 p.m. on the 18th and so it was too late for despatch on that date but that he despatched it duly on the 19th,

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted appellant of charge under s.52 (theft and secreting).

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of the evidence the Sessions Judge held that the charge under s. 52 of the Indian Post Office Act for the theft of currency numbere and for secreting the registered articles had number been established and acquitted him of that charge.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s.55 for fraudulent alteration of lists.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, found it proved that the appellant bad fraudulently altered the lists of registered articles and thereby companymitted an offence under s. 55 of the Indian Post Office Act.

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted appellant under s.53 for wilful detention, sentenced 2 months imprisonment each, concurrent.

anchor.surface_text: He also held that the appellant had wilfully detained the envelope and thus companymitted an offence under s. 53 of the Indian Post Office Act. He accordingly companyvicted the appellant of the charges under Ss. 53 and 55 of the Indian Post Office Act and sentenced him to undergo two months imprisonment on each charge. The sentences were directed to run companycurrently.

facts.text: Mysore High Court set aside conviction under s.55 but maintained conviction under s.53.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal. the High Court of Mysore set aside the ap- pellants companyviction under s. 55 of the Indian Post Office Act but maintained his companyviction under s. 53,

facts.text: High Court found wilful detention proved but alterations not established.

anchor.surface_text: being of opinion that while the wilful detention of the envelope by the appellant had been proved, the alleged alterations by him in the list of registered articles had number been established.

facts.text: Appellant Ramchandra Narasimha Kulkarni preferred appeal against High Court decision.

anchor.surface_text: Against the High Courts decision the present appeal has been preferred by the appellant, Ramchandra Narasimha Kulkarni.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court conviction and sentence under s.53, acquitted appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the order of companyviction and sentence passed by the High Court and order that the appellant be acquitted of the charge against him.

facts.text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL J dissented, would dismiss appeal and uphold conviction under s.53.

anchor.surface_text: I would, therefore, dismiss the appeal.

facts.text: Envelope addressed to Reserve Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: when the Reserve Bank of India, to which this envelope was addressed

facts.text: Petition asked for exchange of half ten-rupee note for fresh note.

anchor.surface_text: petition on behalf of one Muppayyagonda asking for the said numbere to be exchanged for a fresh numbere

facts.text: High Court rejected appellant's claim of late receipt at 5.30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention that it was received after the despatch of the mail has number been accepted.

issues.text: The main question to determine, in this case, is what the expression wilfully detains or delays in s. 53 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898 (Act VI of 1898), hereinafter called the Act, means.

anchor.surface_text: RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-The main question to determine, in this case, is what the expression wilfully detains or delays in s. 53 of the Indian Post Office Act, 1898 (Act VI of 1898), hereinafter called the Act, means.

issues.text: assuming that the envelope was detained by the appellant as alleged, he cannot be said to have detained it wilfully unless it is shown that he had some purpose in doing it

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that assuming that the envelope was detained by the appellant as alleged, he cannot be said to have detained it wilfully unless it is shown that he had some purpose in doing it. But, the purpose alleged by the prosecution was that he wanted to commit theft of the currency note, and to cover thi

anchor.surface_text: I am further of opinion that even if the expression wilfully detains in s. 53 of the Act means a detention deliberate and for some purpose, the appellant is not entitled to an acquittal on the findings the Courts have arrived at. The appellant, in ordinary course of business, would have forwarded

But, the purpose alleged by the prosecution was that he wanted to commit theft of the currency note

arguments.claim: Meaning of wilful/wilfully varies by context and must be ascertained from scheme of legislation

anchor.surface_text: A review of these various decisions brings out clearly the guiding principle that the meaning to be attached to the words wilful or wilfully has to be ascertained on a close examination of the scheme and nature of the legislation in which the words appear and the context in which they are used.

arguments.claim: Comparative punishments in Chapter X show s.53 wilful detention is serious, requires deliberate and purposeful detention

anchor.surface_text: This comparison clearly shows that the legislature took a more serious view of the offence of wilful detention of a postal article s. 52 than of many other offences in this Chapter. Delay in the conveyance or delivery of a mail bag or other postal articles in the course of transmission by a person employed to carry the same is made punishable with only a fine of Rs. 501- s. 49

arguments.claim: Heavy punishment for s.53 (2 years) vs lighter for s.49,50,51 indicates wilful means deliberate and for some purpose

anchor.surface_text: Is it reasonable to think that the legislature would prescribe this heavy punishment for detention of a postal article which was not deliberate and on purpose, while prescribing lighter punishment as mentioned above for the offences under Ss. 49, 50 and 51. We do not think so.

arguments.claim: s.52 uses 'for any purpose whatsoever' for secretion etc., implies s.53 wilfully also requires purpose

anchor.surface_text: It is interesting to notice in this connection that in the preceding section 52 the legislature after making punishable the offence of theft of a postal article or of dishonest misappropriation of the same, also made punishable the secretion, destruction or throwing away any postal article if done for any purpose whatsoever.

arguments.claim: No purpose proved for detention, so not wilful; detention due to inadvertence/carelessness/negligence

anchor.surface_text: There is, therefore, no escape from the conclusion that the detention was not deliberate and on purpose, but as a result of either inadvertence or carelessness or negligence. So, the appellant cannot be said to have detained or delayed the article wilfully.

arguments.claim: Wilfully detains in s.53 means intentional and deliberate, opposed to negligence or inadvertence

anchor.surface_text: I do not agree that it means such detention which was deliberate and for some purpose. I am of opinion that the detention or delay would be wilful if it was intentional and deliberate on the part of the officer of the post office, as opposed to detention or delay on account of negligence or inadvertence.

anchor.surface_text: The word wilful or wilfully used in other enactments have been construed by Court in this manner. I may refer to some of these cases. In Taylor v. Vergette wilful delay has been construed to mean intentional delay. Wilfully means that the act is done deliberately and intentionally, not by accident or inadvertence

arguments.claim: s.52 requires purpose expressly ('for any purpose whatsoever'), s.53 wilfully does not require specific purpose

anchor.surface_text: The legislature, where it intended to make the purpose behind an act an ingredient of the offence, expressly stated so. If the word wilful or wilfully is used in the Act as a synonym for an act done deliberately and for some purpose, the expression wilfully could have been used in the place of for any purpose whatsoever.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal. the High Court of Mysore set aside the appellants conviction under s. 55 of the Indian Post Office Act but maintained his conviction under s. 53, being of opinion that while the wilful detention of the envelope by the appellant had been proved, the alleged alterations by him in the list of registered articles had not been established.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, found it proved that the appellant had fraudulently altered the lists of registered articles and thereby committed an offence under s. 55 of the Indian Post Office Act. He also held that the appellant had wilfully detained the envelope and thus committed an offence under s. 53 of the Indian Post Office Act.

holdings.text: The word 'wilful' in section 53 of the Indian Post Office Act means only such detention which was deliberate and for some purpose.

anchor.surface_text: justifies, in our opinion, the conclusion that the word wilful was used by the legislature to mean only such detention which was deliberate and for some purpose. It is interesting to notice in this connection that

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Chapter X shows heavier punishment for s.53 compared to ss.49-51; contrast with s.52 requiring 'for any purpose whatsoever' indicates purpose needed for wilfulness.

holdings.text: The detention of the postal article by the appellant was not deliberate and for some purpose but resulted from inadvertence, carelessness or negligence, hence not wilful under s.53.

anchor.surface_text: The existence of that purpose has not, however, been established. Nothing was suggested before us as to, what other purpose the appellant could have had in detaining the article. There is, therefore, noescape

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution's alleged purpose (theft and cover-up) not proved; no other purpose suggested or evident; detention too late for dispatch rejected but no purpose shown.

holdings.text: The appellant is acquitted of the charge under s.53 of the Indian Post Office Act.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we allow the appeal, set aside the order of conviction and sentence passed by the High Court and order that the appellant be acquitted of the charge against him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since detention not wilful, offence under s.53 not established.

holdings.text: 'Wilfully detains or delays' in s.53 means detention or delay which was intentional and deliberate on the part of the officer, as opposed to on account of negligence or inadvertence.

anchor.surface_text: I do not agree that it means such detention which was deliberate and for some purpose. I am of opinion that the detention or delay would be wilful if it was intentional and deliberate on the

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supported by precedents (Taylor v. Vergette, Reg. v. Senior, etc.); internal provisions (ss.6,48) distinguish wilful from accidental; not requiring specific purpose.

holdings.text: Even assuming 'wilfully detains' requires detention deliberate and for some purpose, the appellant detained wilfully as he deliberately detained suspecting contents.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Late receipt claim rejected; ordinary course required dispatch on 18th; detention deliberate to examine suspected contents.

anchor.surface_text: a wilful act.  Re Young and Harston  1 . Often, it has been said that the word wilful suggests bad conduct or action though it does number necessarily companynote blame.  Wheeler v. New Merton Board Mills  2  Not infrequently the word has been used to mean that the act had been done with a bad purpose or without justifiable excuse or stubbornly, obstinately or perversely.  United States of America v. Harry Murdock  3 . Some decisions stress the requirement of deliberation or reckless disregard of the fact whether the act was or was number in breach of duty in deciding whether it has been wilful.  Hudson v. Official Liquidator 4  and In re T.N.K. Govindarajulu Chetty  5 .

Some decisions stress the requirement of deliberation or reckless disregard of the fact whether the act was or was number in breach of duty in deciding whether it has been wilful.  Hudson v. Official Liquidator 4  and In re T.N.K. Govindarajulu Chetty  5 . In the last mentioned case, viz., In re T.N.K. Govindarajulu Chettys case, the Madras High Court held that a submission of a false return cannot be a wilful submission unless the dealer has deliberately made the return with the knowledge that he was excluding a taxable item, though in almost similar circumstances another Bench of the same High Court took a different view and held that even though when an assessee, under the impression that a particular item is number taxable and, therefore, need be excluded in the return, omits lo make a mention, of it in the return which he furnished with the full knowledge of his having companymitted the same, he has wilfully omitted it.  In re Jayarama Chettiar   6 .
